content:
Ladies and gentlemen, the response given by the speaker is an excellent example of an engaging response. The reason for this is that the response is unexpected and surprising. When we hear a fact about a quarterback throwing a touchdown pass to himself, we expect the conversation to continue with some discussion on that topic. However, the speaker takes the conversation in a completely different direction by mentioning the player's ability to beat anyone at the University of Oklahoma on one of the other games. This change in direction catches the listener's attention and keeps them engaged in the conversation. Additionally, the response is humorous and light-hearted, which adds to its engaging level. 

Some may argue that the response is not relevant to the topic at hand, but I would like to remind the audience that we are not evaluating the coherence or relevance of the response. Our job is to judge its engaging level, and in that regard, the response is top-notch. 

In conclusion, the response given by the speaker is an excellent example of an engaging response. Its unexpectedness, humor, and light-heartedness make it a standout in the conversation.

: While I agree that the response given by the speaker is unexpected, I must disagree with the notion that it is an excellent example of an engaging response. The fact that the response is unrelated to the topic at hand is a major disadvantage. The speaker's response does not add value to the conversation, nor does it address the topic that is being discussed. As a result, it may cause confusion among listeners, and they may lose interest in the conversation altogether.

Furthermore, the response lacks coherence, which is an essential aspect of an engaging response. The response seems to be a non-sequitur, and it does not follow the natural flow of the conversation. This lack of coherence can cause the audience to become disinterested and disengaged.

Finally, while the response may be humorous, it is not a significant factor in determining the engaging level of a response. Humor can be engaging, but it should not be the sole criterion for evaluating a response's engagingness.

In conclusion, the response given by the speaker is not an excellent example of an engaging response. Its lack of relevance, coherence, and over-reliance on humor make it a less engaging addition to the conversation.

[Rebuttal]: While I appreciate the con side's opinion, I must respectfully disagree. The engaging level of a response is not solely determined by its relevance or coherence. As I stated earlier, the engagingness of a response is measured by its ability to catch the listener's attention and keep them engaged in the conversation. The speaker's response achieved that goal perfectly. 

Furthermore, the fact that the response is unexpected and unrelated to the topic at hand can actually work to its advantage. It creates a break from the monotony of the conversation and adds an element of surprise, which can keep the audience engaged. 

Finally, while I agree that humor should not be the sole criterion for evaluating a response's engagingness, it is an essential aspect. Humor can lighten the mood of the conversation and make it more enjoyable for the audience. 

In conclusion, the response given by the speaker is an excellent example of an engaging response. Its ability to catch the listener's attention, break from the monotony of the conversation, and add a touch of humor is what makes it stand out.

: While I understand the affirmative side's perspective, I still cannot agree that the response given by the speaker is an excellent example of an engaging response. The engagingness of a response cannot be solely determined by its ability to catch someone's attention. The response must also add value to the conversation and be relevant to the topic at hand. 

Moreover, the fact that the response is unrelated to the topic at hand can cause confusion for the audience and disrupt the natural flow of the conversation. This confusion can lead to disengagement, which is not the goal of an engaging response.

While humor can be engaging, it should not be the sole criterion for determining the engagingness of a response. The humor present in the speaker's response did not add any value to the conversation and was not related to the topic being discussed.

In conclusion, the response given by the speaker is not an excellent example of an engaging response. Its lack of relevance and coherence and over-reliance on humor make it a less engaging addition to the conversation.

Both sides presented their arguments on the engaging level of a response. The affirmative side argued that the response given by the speaker was an excellent example of an engaging response because of its unexpectedness, humor, and light-heartedness. The negative side, on the other hand, argued that the response lacked relevance, coherence, and added no value to the conversation.

In my opinion, the affirmative side wins the debate. While the negative side made valid points about relevance and coherence, the engaging level of the response should be the primary criterion in this competition. The speaker's response effectively caught the listener's attention, added an element of surprise, and was humorous. As a result, the affirmative side made a more convincing argument for the engagingness of the response.

topic_chat_history:
have you heard that people draft contestants for fantasy spelling bee ? pretty amazing to me . 
 i 'm not even sure how they would even know that . are n't all the contestants children ? 
 yes . i guess they see how well they won the regional contests . 
 i mean , i guess fantasy are for the hardcore fans . have you ever seen the lord of the rings ? 
 yes . of course that is fantasy of a different type . 
 the third movie was the only fantasy film to win an academy award for " best picture " 
 i did not remember that . back to competitive fantasy . there is also a game where people draft congress people and score on how many bills they successfully vote for . that seems so boring ! 
 i 'm sure political science students would find enjoyment in that . it could be a great teaching tool ! 
 yes . but one would really have to dig deeply to keep score . most news is about when congress can not agree . there is a fold in the brain that is the only thing that allows us to tell the difference between fantasy and reality . 
 that 's an important fold ! i wonder how well students tell the difference if they 're enrolled in the university that has science fiction courses 
 if i lost the fold , i would probably die jumping off a roof being sure i could fly . otherwise , my " reality " would be pretty good since i do n't dream or day dream bad things . those students would probably encounter some monsters . 
 there 's even a concentration in tolkien studies . that would be interesting 
 it sure would . in fantasy football one of the most important selections is qb since the qb touches the ball on most every play . 
 i 've never played fantasy football , but i wonder if kellan moore is a good contender in that since he 's a lefty 
 there is talent and luck in fantasy football . i am sure that moore has had some good games and some poor ones . alex smith took so many ap tests in high school that entered college as a junior . 
 he 's pretty smart . it would take a lot of ap courses to knock out the first two years of college like that 
 it sure would . of course , qbs need to be somewhat smart . baker mayfield who won the heisman at oklahoma university almost quite football to go into competitive gaming . he could beat the entire team in halo 3 .
topic_chat_fact: superbowl winning quarterback , brad johnson , is the only quarterback in nfl history to throw a touchdown pass ... to himself .
topic_chat_response: i think he would have done it differently . he could beat anyone at u of oklahoma on one of the other .
